Beijing Key Laboratory of Solid State Battery and Energy Storage Process Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 PR China The synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO₂ and methanol possesses economic and environmental advantages but faces thermodynamic constraints due to its positive Gibbs free energy change. To address this limitation, we developed a heterogeneous catalytic system employing polystyrene-supported ionic liquids ([BIm]2[CO3]@PS) with imidazolium cations and carbonate anions, combined with Cs2CO3 additives. This system facilitates a novel indirect dehydration pathway under mild conditions (70 °C, 1 MPa CO2), achieving 50.2 % DMC yield with 96.4 % selectivity. Reaction kinetic analysis revealed a remarkably low activation energy of 36 ± 3 kJ/mol. Mechanistic studies demonstrate that CH2Br2 and Cs2CO3 additives synergistically promote stepwise abstraction of hydrogen and oxygen atoms from reactants, circumventing direct water formation. This work provides an efficient heterogeneous catalytic system with an innovative dehydration strategy for energy-efficient DMC synthesis under ambient operational conditions. Meanwhile, CO2 as a sustainable C₁ feedstock exhibits unique advantages of natural abundance, non-toxicity, and renewability. Its efficient transformation into high value-added chemicals and energy-related products represents a critical strategy for addressing global carbon neutrality challenges [3–5]. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is a low-toxicity and environmental-friendly carbonyl compound. It could be produced from CO2, not only serving as organic intermediates [6], fuel additives [7–9], feedstock for polycarbonates [10], but also being widely applied as green solvents for power battery electrolytes [11,12]. In recent decades, the demand for DMC has been increasing with the development of new energy field, and the global market value of DMC is expected to be more than US$760 million by 2025 [13]. Traditionally, the main synthesis routes of DMC are oxidative carbonylation of methanol [14,15], transesterification of cyclic carbonate with methanol [16,17] and alcoholysis of urea [18–20]. In recent years, the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol has attracted much attention, to overcome the disadvantages of the use of carbon monoxide in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol method, high costs or toxicity in the transesterification method, and high energy consumption for by-product separation in the alcoholysis of urea method [21–23], etc. Furthermore, the raw materials CO2 and methanol are inexpensive and convenient to obtain, not dependent on petroleum resources, and DMC can be produced via a one-step green synthetic procedure from CO2 [24–26]. Nevertheless, the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol faces inherent thermodynamic challenges, primarily manifested by the unfavorable positive Gibbs free energy change (ΔG > 0). In-situ dehydration process is essential to break the thermodynamic limitation and keep the reaction proceeding towards DMC generation [27]. In the absence of the dehydrating agent, the DMC yield is less than 1 % [28–31]. Several dehydrating agents have been developed (Table 1 ). The molecular sieves (MS) and membrane reactors are commonly used as physical dehydrating agents [29,32], which are not as effective as chemical dehydrating agents including 2,2-dimethoxypropane (DMP) [30], 1,1,1-trimethoxymethane (TMM) [31], dicyclohexyl carbodiimide (DCC) [33], 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) [34–39], etc. However, the chemical dehydrating agents are expensive, difficult to be separated and could exert a toxic effect on. Furthermore, relatively harsh conditions are always required (120∼150 °C and >3 MPa CO2) in these dehydration processes [40]. Thermodynamic equations of the ΔG for this reaction [41,42] reveals that the relatively low temperature and high pressure could be favorable to proceed positively [43], as demonstrated in Fig. 1 . Paradoxically, while kinetics dictate that high temperature is beneficial to break through the energy barrier and react rapidly, industrial implementation mandates operation under energy-efficient mild conditions. This fundamental conflict between thermodynamic and kinetic underscores the critical need for innovative dehydration methodologies that simultaneously address equilibrium constraints and rate acceleration. In the conventional dehydration strategy, the dehydrating agents with C = N groups and methoxyalkanes can react with H2O respectively via hydration reaction and hydrolysis reaction in relatively harsh reaction conditions. To further reduce the reaction energy barrier and carry out the reaction under mild conditions, the indirect dehydration strategy that H and O are peeled off from the reactants separately could be promising. Considering that the ionic liquids (ILs) with adjustable structures [44–46] can possess an affinity ability with CO2 and H2O [47], especially the ability to regulate the transfer of H/O through anion and cation [48], which could facilitate the catalysis and dehydration processes [49]. In recent years, the homogeneous composite systems of Base/IL working as both the catalyst and dehydrating agent have been successively explored [50,51]. However, these IL-based homogeneous systems are not easily separated, and the reaction mechanism is ambiguous and the specific co-catalysis mechanism has rarely been investigated. In this study, we present the heterogeneous IL catalytic system ( [Im]2 [CO3]@PS) that implements an innovative indirect dehydration mechanism for the energy-efficient synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol, achieving 50.2 % DMC yield with 96.4 % selectivity. Mechanistic investigations reveal that the Cs2CO3 and CH2Br2 additives synergistically mediate stepwise H and O abstraction: (1) Cs2CO3 extracts H atom to form HCO3 -, while (2) CH2Br2 facilitates O atom transfer through methylal (CH2OCH2OCH3) formation. Compared with the current mainstream CeO2/2-CP catalytic system that requires high temperature and pressure conditions (120∼150 °C and >3 MPa CO2), this indirect dehydration strategy achieves energy-efficient DMC synthesis under ambient pressure conditions (70 °C and 1 MPa). Reaction kinetic analysis revealed a remarkably low activation energy of 36 ± 3 kJ/mol compared to the commercial CeO2 system (117 ± 42 kJ/mol). The methodology provides a promising dehydration strategy for the sustainable synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of PS-Cl-supported ILs The supported ionic liquid catalysts were all synthesized in a two-step method with similar process. The preparation of [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS can be illustrated as an example (Scheme 1 ). The chemicals and reagents used in this study include chloromethylated polystyrene (PS-Cl, Jiangsu Suqing Water Treatment Co., Ltd., China), methanol (99.9 %, Innochem), dibromomethane (CH2Br2, 99 %, Innochem), cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3, 99 %, Innochem), 1-butylimidazole (99 %, Innochem), sodium carbonate anhydrous (99 %, Aladdin). A mixture of PS-Cl (20∼30 mesh), 1-butylimidazole (25 mmol) and THF (50 mL) was heated at 60 °C for 24 h in a 150 mL flask. After cooling down to room temperature, the solid residue was collected by filtration and washed separately with water and ethanol to give [BIm]Cl@PS. The ion exchange process was performed with Na2CO3 solution (0.5 M) until no Cl- was detected. Then the solid residue was filtered and washed with water and ethanol until the filtrate was neutral. Finally, the solid was dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight to give [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS. A preliminary estimate of the cost has been carried out, as shown in Table S2-S3. The feedstock costs for the production of 1 kg catalyst and 1 kg DMC are $12.4 and $46.5, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of the PS-Cl-supported ILs The loading of ILs on the PS-Cl was measured by the elemental analyzer (Vario EL cube). The surface and section morphology of catalysts was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Energy Dispersive X-ray-Spectroscopy (EDS) with Hitachi S-4800. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on a Thermo Nicolet 380 spectrophotometer standardized with anhydrous KBr (spectroscopically pure). The synthesized catalysts were milled before use for characterization. The pore structure of catalysts was explored by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method (ASAP 2020HD88). The adsorption capacity of the catalysts for CO2 was measured on a Chemisorption Analyzer (Nova 2000). Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 70 °C for 12 h. The composition of Cs2CO3 and the reacted solid powder were determined by a Smart Lab X-ray diffractometer (XRD) developed by Rigaku Co. The light source was Cu Kα rays at a wavelength λ = 0.154 nm, the operating voltage was 40 kV, the current was 50 mA, the recording range was 5∼90°, and the scanning speed was 15°/min. The molecular weight of the key component in the reaction liquid and the reacted solid powder were identified using electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). 2.3 The synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol All experiments were carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and an automatic temperature control system. The titrant used for bromine titration was 0.01 mol/L AgNO3 solution and for HCO3 -/CO3 2- acid-base titration was 0.1 mmol/L HCl solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supported ILs The structure of ILs was identified using FT-IR and 13C MAS NMR (Fig. 2 ). In the FT-IR spectrum of PS-Cl (Fig. 2a), the peaks at 1265cm-1 and 670cm-1 arise from the CCl bond. When the ILs were grafted onto the PS-Cl, the CCl bond was broken and the CN bond appeared. The characteristic peak of CN bond is exhibited at 3300 cm-1. The peaks at 1624 cm-1 and 1566 cm-1 belong to the C = C and C = N bonds of imidazole, respectively [52]. A clear in-plane deformation vibration of imidazole and triazole is near 1158 cm-1 [53]. The distinct characteristic peak of C = O bond stretching vibration at 1658 cm-1 belongs to CO3 2- anions [54]. The above information indicates that all CO3 2- ILs were successfully introduced onto PS-Cl. The structure of [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS was further analyzed using solid-state 13C NMR. The 13C NMR spectrum of PS-Cl is demonstrated in Fig. S3. As shown in Fig. 2b, the chemical shifts of the imidazole ring C atoms were observed at 8, 9 and 10. In addition, [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS showed a typical peak at 15 attributed to the CO3 2- group [55], demonstrating the successful synthesis of supported ILs [56–58]. The loadings of ILs were quantitatively determined through elemental analysis of nitrogen content, as shown in Table 2 . The loadings of imidazole (2.8–3.2 mmol/g) demonstrate consistency with the theoretical loading [53]. Although the triazole is less basic than imidazole due to the number of nitrogen atoms, which is less likely to bond with the C atom on PS-Cl. Hence, the loading of [1,2,4-triazole]2 [CO3] is only 0.198 mmol/g. The morphology and elemental distribution of PS-Cl and [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS were characterized through SEM and EDS (Fig. 3 ). PS-Cl exhibited a plain surface, while the [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS displayed a rough surface with small pits. Moreover, the corresponding EDS elemental mappings of the [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS indicate that the imidazolium ILs were uniformly distributed onto PS-Cl. The textural properties of catalysts were characterized by BET. Fig. 4 (a) shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts and exhibits the characteristics of IV-type isothermal adsorption-desorption curves. Corresponding BJH pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 4 (b) and the surface area and pore size are concluded in Table S1. It can be seen that there is no significant change in surface area and the pore size of the catalyst was obviously reduced after loading ILs. Imidazolium ILs can form NHCCO2 adducts with CO2 [50]. Fig. 5 illustrates the adsorption capacity of the catalysts for CO2 at room temperature. The adsorption capacity for CO2 of PS-Cl loaded with ILs was all enhanced obviously. Among the catalysts loaded with imidazolium ILs, [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS shows the best CO2 adsorption capacity. This is due to the concentration of NHCCO2 ascends with the steric hindrance of imidazole cations [59]. Among them, [1,2,4-triazole]2 [CO3]@PS shows the smallest CO2 adsorption capacity, probably due to its lowest IL loading. 3.2 Catalytic activities of catalysts Fig. 6 demonstrates the catalytic activity of the five catalysts. The activity is in the following order: butyl imidazole > propyl imidazole > ethyl imidazole > methyl imidazole > 1,2,4-triazole. Results show that long-chain cations are favorable for improving the catalytic activity [60,61]. Moreover, [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS exhibits the best activity, which is attributed to excellent CO2 adsorption capacity. The C2 in imidazole ILs can easily convert to N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) via removing the H +, and the lone pair of electrons of NHCs could activate the CO2 by attacking the C atom of CO2 through nucleophilic attack [62]. [1,2,4-triazole]2 [CO3]@PS has poor catalytic activity with only 2.8 % DMC yield, which may be due to low IL loading. To obtain the optimum reaction conditions for the catalytic reaction of [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS, the effects of reaction conditions were investigated, including reaction temperature, pressure, time, methanol and Cs2CO3 dosage (Fig. 7 ). Moreover, due to the low boiling point of CH2Br2, some of the substance may be taken away during CO2 venting and lead to bias especially when the yield is low. Therefore, the following discussion is based on the change in yields. The methanol conversions are shown in Fig. S4. Firstly, the effect of temperature was investigated in Fig. 7 (a). The yields of DMC exhibited a volcano-shaped profile with optimal productivity (50.2 %) achieved at 70 °C. It’s due to the amounts of by-products (formaldehyde, methylal (DMM), as evidenced by GC–MS (Fig. S5-S9)) increase with increasing temperature, resulting in the decrease in the selectivity of DMC. When the temperature increased to 110 °C, the conversion of methanol increased because of the side reaction of methanol with the by-product formaldehyde to form DMM [63]. Moreover, we observed a darkening of the catalyst at 110 °C, likely attributable to imidazolium ring decomposition, which is responsible for the decrease in catalytic activity. As illustrated in Fig. 7 (b), the effect of pressure was investigated. The yield of DMC increased as the pressure increased and reached the maximum at 1 MPa. Continuing to increase pressure has little effect on reactivity. Fig. 7 (c) shows the effect of reaction time. The yield increased as the reaction time extended to 12 h. Further extension of the reaction time had little effect on catalytic activity. Moreover, the yield of the by-product DMM was gradually increasing as the reaction time was prolonged. The catalytic potential and broad applicability in carbonate synthesis were also investigated (Table 3 ). Among the monohydric alcohols, methanol has the highest activity for the generation of carbonates. On the one hand, it’s due to the high polarity of methanol that the H on the hydroxy is more easily to be removed. On the other hand, it may be due to the small spatial site resistance of DMC that the reaction is more likely to be carried out. The effect of different haloalkane solvents on the reaction performance was further explored (Fig. 8 ). Among them, bromoalkanes are considerably more active than chloroalkanes, and CH2Br2 exhibits the best reactivity as solvent. Alkane solvents with double halogenation on a single carbon atom exhibited better performance than that on two carbon atoms. The reaction performance of haloalkane solvents with double halogenation on two carbon atoms decreased as the substituent position distances increased. In conclusion, CH2Br2 was chosen as the solvent for the reaction. 3.3 Study of reaction mechanism for the synthesis of DMC Lim et al. [66] developed Cs2CO3 as the catalyst for the synthesis of carbonates from alcohols, proposing a reaction mechanism in which Cs2CO3 is involved in the reaction and reacts with the solvent CH2Br2 to form CsBr. However, there is no effective verification. Moreover, given that CH3I is commonly used as alkylating reagents [67,68], it is hypothesized that CH2Br2 may also act as alkylating reagent facilitating the conversion of methanol and CO2 to DMC [69]. In order to investigate the influence of each component in the system on the reaction mechanism, a series of substrate control experiments were conducted (Scheme 2 ). It can be seen that catalysts, methanol and Cs2CO3 are indispensable for the synthesis of DMC Scheme 2 (2, 3, 4). It was found that the yield of DMC was 18 % without the addition of CO2 Scheme 2 (5), indicating that the carbonyl group in the product DMC is not only derived from CO2. In conclusion, for the generation of DMC, there are two reaction paths. One is involved by CO2, where the carbonyl group is derived from CO2. And the other is generated in the absence of CO2 by the carbonyl group of Cs2CO3. Based on these results, we speculate that Cs2CO3 is involved in the reaction at least in the condition of without CO2. Subsequently, we further characterized the post-reaction solid powder residues. In Fig. 9 a, the XRD pattern of the sample exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 14.9, 15.9, 20.7, 26.4, 27.0, 29.3, 31.2, 37.5, 41.9, 52.1, 61, 69.1and 84.2 (°). After the reaction, the peaks of Cs2CO3 (19.2, 28.0,34.3, 40.3 and 45.6°) decreased or even disappeared, and the peaks of CsBr (27.0, 29.3, 41.9, 52.1, 61, 69.1 and 84.2°) and CsHCO3 (14.9, 15.9, 26.4, 27.0, 31.2 and 37.5°) appeared newly. This is consistent with the results of ESI (Fig. 9b), indicating that there was a chemical reaction between Cs2CO3 and CH2Br2. It’s speculated that Cs2CO3 and CH2Br2 participated in the process of generating DMC as reactants, which is different from the mechanism speculated in previous literature [50]. Cs2CO3 not only act as an additive to enhance the basicity, but also as a reactant. CH2Br2 was also more than just solvent, and most likely participated in the reaction as an alkylation reagent with the elemental Br stripped off. As the key components CH2Br2 and Cs2CO3 are converted to CsBr and CsHCO3. To elucidate the role of CH2Br2 and Cs2CO3 during the catalytic cycle, we quantified the Br- content of the post-reaction solid powder residues. As depicted in Fig. 10 , the yield of DMC and the Br- content in the solid powder gradually increased with the increase of reaction time, which provides quantitative evidence for the progressive involvement of CH2Br2 in the catalytic network. The longer the reaction time, the more CH2Br2 was involved in the reaction. Fig. 11 demonstrates the ions content of the post-reaction solid powder residues under different reaction conditions, where the amount of Cs+ is the sum of Br-, CO3 2- and HCO3 -. When the product DMC was generated (A, B), CO3 2- was not detected in the post-reaction solid powder residues. However, when no DMC was generated (C), there were large amounts of CO3 2-. It’s indicated that the "additive Cs2CO3″ participates in the title reaction and transformed to CsBr and CsHCO3 completely. In the CO2-involved pathway, more CsHCO3 was produced (A). In the absence of CO2, CsBr and CsHCO3 were produced close to 1:1 (B). It's possible that more CH2Br2 was involved in the reaction in the absence of CO2. Moreover, it can be clearly seen that the addition of catalyst significantly promoted the transformation of Cs2CO3 and CH2Br2 to CsHCO3 and CsBr (B, C). Furthermore, the reaction liquids were characterized using electrospray ESI-MS and GC–MS. Slight amounts of Br- and HCO3 - were detected by ESI (Fig. S11). What’s more, in addition to DMM, a small amount of formaldehyde was detected in the reaction liquids (Fig. S5-S6) which may be the products of CH2Br2. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanisms for the synthesis of DMC Based on the experimental results and previous reports, possible reaction mechanism in two pathways is proposed as shown in Scheme 3 . Firstly, the H protons on the azocarbon A in the imidazole catalyst are taken away by alkaline Cs2CO3 to form the active species azacarbene B. Subsequently, CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst is activated by the active species B to form [BIm]-CO2 adduct C, which can react with CH2Br2 by the nucleophilic attack to generate intermediate D. In Pathway I, methanol deprotonates to form methoxy and HCO3 - in the presence of basic CO3 2-, and the nucleophilic methoxide then attacks the carbon atom in D to generate E and F. Then, the crucial intermediate G has been released, which can be evidenced by the ESI ( [M + H +]170.16) (Fig. S11). G can react with methanol by the transesterification to yield the desired product DMC and release the unstable by-product bromomethanol (CH2BrOH) [70]. CH2BrOH could probably remove HBr to form formaldehyde and further DMM in the presence of methanol (Fig. S5-S6). Pathway II cannot be ruled out, and after the successive introduction of CO2 and CH2Br2 from A to D, methanol react with D through the transesterification to produce E’ and CH2BrOH. Then the second molecule of methanol can nucleophilically attack to the carbonyl of E’ to form F’ and G’. Finally, DMC can be successfully released from G’. In the synthetic process of DMC, H and O elements from methanol and CO2 can be inferred to be peeled off respectively. The protons can be easily converted into HCO3 - in the presence of basic Cs2CO3, and O atom could be fixed in succession by CH2BrOH, formaldehyde. Moreover, CH2BrOH and formaldehyde are both unstable, and the last mode of O element would probably be H2O and HCO3 - in presence of excess CO2, accompanied by the formation of DMM. In the catalytic cycles, formaldehyde and DMM can be detected in the GC–MS after the reaction (Fig. S6). In addition, DMC can also be generated in the absence of CO2. The possible mechanism is shown in Scheme 4 . Unlike the mechanism in Scheme 3, the carbonyl group for the synthesis of DMC originates from the CO3 2- of Cs2CO3. Firstly, CO3 2- react with CH2Br2 by the nucleophilic attack (ⅰ-ⅱ). Then the intermediates react with methanol by the transesterification to yield the product DMC and release CH2BrOH (ⅲ-ⅳ). The following reaction is the same as Scheme 3 (ⅴ-ⅵ). In brief, to produce one molecule of DMC requires the consumption of two molecules of CH2Br2 and hence double of Br- is also produced and fixed by Cs+ to afford CsBr, which is consistent with the Br- content in Fig. 9. 3.5 Kinetics study of the direct synthesis of DMC As the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol is a slow reaction, we focus on utilizing the initial rates of conversion in order to determine the activation energy (E a) and reaction order. In aim to explore the reaction trend of [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS catalyzed direct synthesis of DMC from CO2/methanol, the kinetic results at three different temperatures (with consistent methanol concentration) were experimentally determined according to the Arrhenius equation to calculate the E a of the reaction [71]. As shown in Fig. 12 (a), a linear fit of the Arrhenius plot shows a slope of −4353.2, which indicated an apparent activation energy of 36 ± 3 kJ/mol for the [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS catalyst. According to the previous literature, the Ea of the commercial CeO2 catalyst for this reaction system is 117 ± 42 kJ/mol [72]. It can be seen that the catalytic system used in this work greatly reduces the reaction energy barrier, and relatively high reaction activity can be obtained under milder conditions. The reaction order of MeOH was calculated by varying the amount of different MeOH additions while maintaining a constant 1 MPa reaction pressure, consistent amounts of CO2, and a consistent reaction temperature of 70 °C. Graphically, the reaction order of methanol is about 0.55 ± 0.14, as shown in Fig. 12(b). According to previous literature [71], the reaction order of methanol is about −1.0 when no dehydrating agent is added, and the methanol concentration is negatively correlated with the reaction rate. This indicates that the concentration of methanol is positively correlated with the reaction rate in the synthesis of DMC in the [BIm]2 [CO3]@PS/CH2Br2/Cs2CO3 system. It may be due to this catalytic system enables indirect dehydration and promotes the reaction in a positive direction. It is hypothesized that this catalytic reaction system is different from the conventional reaction route for the direct synthesis of DMC. 4 Conclusions In this study, [BIm]2 [CO3] combined with additives have been exploited as the heterogeneous-IL catalytic system, which goes through a novel indirect dehydration strategy. The strategy achieves the DMC yield of 50.2 % and the selectivity of 96.4 % under mild conditions (70 °C, 1 MPa CO2). Compared with the current mainstream CeO2/2-CP catalytic system that requires high temperature and pressure conditions (120∼150 °C and >3 MPa CO2), this strategy achieves energy-efficient DMC synthesis. Through comprehensive exploration, we elucidated an innovative indirect dehydration mechanism. Remarkably, this indirect dehydration strategy illustrates that H and O elements are peeled off from the reactants separately by CO3 2- and CH2Br2 into HCO3 - and H2O, rather than the direction formation of H2O molecules with the further hydration and hydrolysis reactions, thus facilitating the mild homogeneous transformation in heterogeneous systems. Moreover, the system overcomes the thermodynamic limitation and dehydration obstacles, showing a much low activation energy (36 ± 3kJ/mol). This work not only presents a highly efficient and energy-conscious catalytic strategy for DMC production but also establishes a groundbreaking framework for indirect dehydration methodologies in CO2 utilization. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO₂ and methanol possesses economic and environmental advantages but faces thermodynamic constraints due to its positive Gibbs free energy change. To address this limitation, we developed a heterogeneous catalytic system employing polystyrene-supported ionic liquids ([BIm]2[CO3]@PS) with imidazolium cations and carbonate anions, combined with Cs2CO3 additives. This system facilitates a novel indirect dehydration pathway under mild conditions (70 °C, 1 MPa CO2), achieving 50.2 % DMC yield with 96.4 % selectivity. Reaction kinetic analysis revealed a remarkably low activation energy of 36 ± 3 kJ/mol. Mechanistic studies demonstrate that CH2Br2 and Cs2CO3 additives synergistically promote stepwise abstraction of hydrogen and oxygen atoms from reactants, circumventing direct water formation. This work provides an efficient heterogeneous catalytic system with an innovative dehydration strategy for energy-efficient DMC synthesis under ambient operational conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient and Mild CO2 conversion to dimethyl carbonate via heterogeneous ionic liquid catalysis: An indirect dehydration approach
